title: Ireland 42-14 Japan: Irish end eight-year World Cup wait with 'one of best ever performances'
description: Injured Ireland back row Dorothy Wall says Ireland ended their eight-year World Cup wait with one of their "best ever performances" against Japan.
content:
For Ireland, eight years was - at least for now - worth the wait.

For women's rugby in Ireland, the gap between World Cup appearances featured the scarring lows of a shock qualifying elimination in 2021, a Six Nations wood spoon and concerns over facilities and playing conditions.

However, the rebuild under Scott Bemand over the past two years has been impressive - and perhaps swifter than many would have anticipated.

There were the confidence-boosting scalps of New Zealand and Australia last year, and a return to form in the Six Nations.

And when the time for talking was over as Ireland returned to the sport's biggest stage on Sunday, they delivered in style against Japan.

"It was amazing, I'm so proud of each and every one of them," said injured Ireland back row Dorothy Wall.

"It's probably one of the best performances we've ever put in as a team.

"From set piece to how we managed the game, we executed well and I'm so proud of the entire squad."

Former Ireland forward and BBC Sport pundit Anna Caplice added Ireland had "turned it around" after a difficult few years.

"Japan aren't to be messed around with," she said.

"It was never going to be a gimme. So to put in a full 80-minute performance was brilliant for Ireland."

keywords.name: injured Ireland back row Dorothy Wall
Former Ireland forward and BBC Sport pundit Anna Caplice

summary: Ireland ended their eight-year wait for the World Cup with a 42-14 victory over Japan, marking a significant turnaround for the country's women's rugby team. The team's rebuild under Scott Bemand has been successful, with recent victories against New Zealand and Australia and a return to form in the Six Nations. The victory was seen as one of the best performances they've ever played, with injured Ireland back row Dorothy Wall describing the performance as "amazing".
shortSummary: Ireland ended an eight-year wait for women's rugby by defeating Japan 42-14 in their World Cup opener, with standout performances from both teams.
argos_summary: Ireland’s women’s rugby team has rebounded from a disappointing 2021 World Cup qualification exit and a Six Nations wood‑spoon, thanks to a swift rebuild under coach Scott Bemand. After defeating New Zealand and Australia in the lead‑up and regaining form in the Six Nations, they returned to the World Cup stage and delivered a standout 80‑minute victory over Japan. Players and pundits alike praised the team’s set‑piece execution and overall performance, marking what many see as one of the best displays in Irish rugby history.
